channel.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
channel.description: When an album is released, the author makes little or no money at all. The songs all goes towards the artist's concerts and such. So, should it really be illegal?

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @Zach1188 Zach1188
item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

Here’s my philosophy; if the album is good enough for me to buy it, then I will. But if it isn’t, and I’m not going to buy it anyway, then I see no problem in downloading the album, because they get the same amount of money either way.

Same applies with games, programs, movies, or anything that can be acquired on a torrent.

Read full topic
item.source: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @phonnygoblin phonnygoblin
item.description:
@phonnygoblin wrote:

Unid H4x0r:

When an album is released, the author makes little or no money at all. The songs all goes towards the artist’s concerts and such. So, should it really be illegal?

Cause I forgot that the people selling the records don’t deserve money, and are only there to not give much money to the artists.

Read full topic

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

You got it backwards.
Touring is so people buy their album.

item.source: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @goatee goatee
item.description:
@goatee wrote:

Yes, if you download a song and you like it… you’re going to buy their other songs? No, you’ll just download the others. If it were harder to download music then people would actually buy it, or listen to the radio, allowing bands/record companies to charge higher royalties.

Read full topic
item.source: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“goatee, post:64, topic:228175”][quote author=bowserjr2 link=topic=299922.msg2411630#msg2411630 date=1219957100]
My point is that when you download a song, and you are making your own Ferrari, the shop does not lose anything
[/quote]

It loses a paying customer?[/quote]
Not if you never would buy the product at all.
Instead they can earn a paying customer, if you like the song you maybe buy more of the same group, if you like Ferrari you maybe buy someone later.

Read full topic

item.source: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Mopman:

By that same logic, you didn’t have the song in the first place, so you gain it. Therefore it is stealing, by your logic?

No it isn’t, they don’t lose anything. If I’d steal a cd from a shop it would be different, but music sharing doesn’t need something physical, and it can be copied. It’s the same as copying a book on your own paper, its not stealing, its copyright infrignement (sp?).

Read full topic
item.source: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

I don’t consider myself stealing anything when I download any warez/music.

I guess it’s technically stealing, but when I download stuff they are losing NOTHING from it. I wouldn’t purchase the music in the first place, even if I had no way of downloading. So it’s not like they lose potential money from me buying it. I simply cannoy afford to listen to music if I had to pay. Plus I’m not breaking any laws here in my country by downloading music. So I guess by law, it is not stealing here.

Read full topic
item.source: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

Yes artists don’t get money, but they didn’t have that money in the first place so they don’t loose it.

By that same logic, you didn’t have the song in the first place, so you gain it. Therefore it is stealing, by your logic?

item.source: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Like bowserjr2 said, it’s not stealing. Stealing is taking away something that someone else possesses, like stealing a car or something not physical like a runescape account or whatever. Downloading music is not stealing, as noone possesses that specific items that you download. Noone looses something. Yes artists don’t get money, but they didn’t have that money in the first place so they don’t loose it.

Read full topic
item.source: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“The Reaper X, post:53, topic:228175”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=299922.msg2411730#msg2411730 date=1219960284]

I don’t have to pay a cent, and that still isn’t fair. I give them what I think is the amount they get. Do I have to? No, I choose to. I could choose to purchase the CD in full, but I don’t do that either. What does it matter if I pay them or not? Other than the obvious. Why call me out, I’m sure you’ve downloaded music illegally, why criticize me for what I do. That’s just being a hypocrite.

Because I admit that when I download music I am commiting a crime, and I am jacking the artist and the label out of the money they deserve. You seem to think that you are being fair (in fact, that was your exact words).

I’m not calling you out, I’m asking how you have rationalised in your mind that what you do is right
[/quote]

basically its like, stealing a Ferrari, but then paying the creator back ^-^ rofl.[/quote]
No, its like build your own Ferrari and pay the creator for the Idea of how build it.
You have to self buy the materials when you copy a CD to a another CD, and when you are building your own Ferrari.

Download music is not legal, but also not STEALING.
Download music is like breaking a patent.
None of it is stealing but still not allowed.
Stop comparing download Music and stealing something from a shop.
Stealing is when you take something from a other person without permission.
When you download with µTorrent/Lime-ware the seeder give you permission to download the file.
Is more like Plagiarism.

Read full topic

item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

It’s not that well thought out, as I said I joined a group that does it. I only did it out of respect for the musicians. Of course there are others that deserve the money just as much. Like I said. I agreed with what R.I.P RSC said.

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman

item.source: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

No, I fully understand the potential consequences of downloading music illegally. I pay them because I joined a group of people that do it. It’s not about slamming the record companies, I just felt it would be considerate to pay for the songs I download. I rather it be the group who created the music than the production companies. I know that it is wrong, no my moral compass isn’t screwed up.

Read full topic

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:48, topic:228175”][quote author=ThAt0n36Uy link=topic=299922.msg2411611#msg2411611 date=1219956540]
What I’ve been doing recently is downloading all the CD’s and songs I want, then sending the band the amount of money they receive from the record companies. I feel that it is fair.
[/quote]

How is that remotely fair?

How do you know how much money the musician would get? Have you read their contract?

Also, you’re now just jacking the label out of money.[/quote]

I don’t have to pay a cent, and that still isn’t fair. I give them what I think is the amount they get. Do I have to? No, I choose to. I could choose to purchase the CD in full, but I don’t do that either. What does it matter if I pay them or not? Other than the obvious. Why call me out, I’m sure you’ve downloaded music illegally, why criticize me for what I do. That’s just being a hypocrite.

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:47, topic:228175”][quote author=The Reaper X link=topic=299922.msg2411620#msg2411620 date=1219956846]

I can’t afford a ferrari, £130k for a car i’ll only drive 5 times a year…? I might aswel just steal one.

It will not be ok, but if you build your own ferrari it will be the same as download a CD.
If you not afford food, then you can grow your own food, not steal it.

Good luck building your own pirate ferrari.

No… making cover songs is like making your own ferrari… You’re a little off.
[/quote]
My point is that when you download a song, and you are making your own Ferrari, the shop does not lose anything, the company thats made the CD or Ferrari does not lose anything.[/quote]
yes, but say that (extreme scenario) 100 people buy the actual CD. and they all upload the songs, and everyone that would have bought the original CD, downloaded it from the people who uploaded it. The artist and cooperatives not not literally lose the money, but they don’t make anything from it. If you made a Ferrari from scratch its not like you actually bought the model and you’re giving it like that.

Read full topic

item.source: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?

item.title: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

Ckstunner should be banned for retardation.

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:41, topic:228175”]Record company’s need the money. They have huge costs for promotion, recording audio/video, tours (yes, they cost money. You have staff, transport, the location costs money, you need equipment and the artists need money too.) The record company has staff costs, and most of them are on the stockmarket, so they have to make profits or else their share price will drop because of low dividends and then they can’t lend more money if they need to.

So yea, record company’s take a lot of the money, but they have more costs then musicians.[/quote]

I agree with this, but I also don’t want to pay 11.00 for a CD that I’ll listen to once a month. When I can wait 2 hours for my computer to download a torrent of the bands whole discography, for free(other than monthly fees for internet). When it comes down to it, stealing music is stealing. Whether it’s digital or walking into a store with a stolen CD in your pocket.

What I’ve been doing recently is downloading all the CD’s and songs I want, then sending the band the amount of money they receive from the record companies. I feel that it is fair.

Read full topic
item.source: Downloading songs illegal - is it really?
